tutorial.title: Form Validator
tutorial.descriptionContent: Use functions to build a form validator

executableContent.instructions:
In this project, we'll be taking user input from a registration form complete with simple validation.

To begin the project, let's take a look at some parts of the code that make the entire website work. We won't focus too much on these parts, but it's good to acknowledge them. 

Take a look at the `onsubmit="formInput(event)"` attribute attached to the `form` element in our `index.html`. We'll use `event` to send over user input captured in the form's `input` elements to `script.js`. We've also started building out `script.js` to help get you started. We'll focus on finishing the form's input function.

1. Inside `script.js`, within the `formInput(e)` function, code `e.preventDefault()`. This is a method call that allows us to prevent the form from being submitted unless all validation checks pass.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
Register Here

Welcome To Your Profile!

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Continue building out our function by assigning the value of each `input` element from our form to their respective variables. 

We'll use `e.target` to point to the form element as a whole. To specify which value we need from an `input` element, refer to the element's `name` attribute. For example, to get the value for the username `input` element, the solution will be `e.target.username.value;`.

1. Assign the `userName` variable a value from the username `input` element. 
2. Assign the `email` variable a value from the email `input` element.
3. Assign the `password` variable a value from the password `input` element.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
Register Here

Welcome To Your Profile!

files.name: style.css
script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. The `userName` variable should be assigned the value `e.target.username.value;`.
2. The `email` variable should be assigned the value `e.target.email.value;`.
3. The `password` variable should be assigned the value `e.target.password.value;`.

executableContent.instructions:
Next, let's create a mock database array and a function to check if a user already exists within the array. 

1. Create a constant `userDatabase` that has a value of an array that includes `"John"`, `"Jane"`, `"Bob"`, and `"Ashley"`. To keep script.js organized, this variable should be placed below the other variables and above `formInput(e)`.
2. Create a function named `checkExistingUser`. This function should also have a parameter named `array`.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
Register Here

Welcome To Your Profile!

files.name: style.css
script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
Arrays are written as `["item1", "item2", "item3"];`.
Functions are written as `function functionName(parameter) {};`

executableContent.instructions:
To check if a username already exists, iterate through the `userDatabase` array.

1. Create a for loop inside the`checkExistingUser` function that will later iterate through the users.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
Register Here

Welcome To Your Profile!

files.name: style.css
script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: To iterate through the length of `userDatabase`, code out a for loop by declaring the variable `i` and initializing it to 0, checking that `i` is less the length of the array, and incrementing `i` by 1 after each pass through the loop.

executableContent.instructions:
In each iteration of our for loop, check if `userName` matches the element in the array.

1. Use an `if` statement to check if `userName` is equal to the current element in the array. If there is a match, write a console message indicating the username is taken. You can write any message but include the word `"taken"`.
2. If there is a match, `checkExistingUser(array)` should also `return` `true`.

files.content:

Welcome To Your Profile!

script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: To check if `userName` is equal to the current element in the array, code out `if(userName === array[i])`. If there is a match, `return true;` inside the `if` statement.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's go back to the `formInput(e)` function that we created in the previous lessons.

Now that the user inputs are stored in the variables and the `checkExistingUser` function is created, we can check to see if the value for `userName` already exists in a mock database.

1. Call `checkExistingUser` inside the `formInput` function and pass in the variable `userDatabase` as an argument.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
Register Here

Welcome To Your Profile!

files.name: style.css
script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Inside `formInput(e)`, code `checkExistingUser(userDatabase);` at the end of the code block.

executableContent.instructions:
Next, create a function that takes in `userName`, `email`, and `password` for simple form validation.

1. Create a function named `formValidate()`. It should have three parameters `usernameVar`, `emailVar`, and `passwordVar`.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
Register Here

Welcome To Your Profile!

files.name: style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Next, let's write an `if` statement that will check if `usernameVar`, `emailVar`, and `passwordVar` are `true`. If the value for any of these variables is an empty string, it will be considered false.

1. Create an `if` statement that checks if `usernameVar`, `emailVar`, and `passwordVar` are true. To do that, code `usernameVar && emailVar && passwordVar` inside the parentheses.
2. When the `if` statement condition is satisfied, print a message to the console that indicates the registration is successful.
3. Also update the `registered` value to be `true`.

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Be sure to use the correct logic to check that all inputs are true.

executableContent.instructions:
Complete the `else` statement for `formValidate()`.

1. Create an `else` statement that prints a message to the console indicating `"All form fields must be filled out"`.

Now that the `formValidate` function is working, `checkExistingUser(array)` should call it to handle simple form validation.

1. Call `formValidate` that takes in `userName`, `email`, and `password` parameters in the `checkExistingUser` function, after the for loop.

hints.content: To call to function`formValidate()`, code out `formValidate(userName, email, password);`within the existing `checkExistingUsers` function.

executableContent.instructions:
Almost done! Now, create the `renderProfile` function, which will take a user to their profile page upon successful registration.

1. Create a function named `renderProfile` that has a parameter meaningfully named `registeredBoolean`.
2. `renderProfile()` should have an `if` statement that checks if `registeredBoolean` is `true`.

1. Call `renderProfile` that takes in `registered` as parameter in the `formValidate` function, inside the if-statement, after `registered` has been set to `true`.
